This Is What You Should Know When Travelling to the Netherlands With Airbnb | by Paul Iusztin | MediumOpen in appSign upSign inWriteSign upSign inMastodonThis Is What You Should Know When Travelling to the Netherlands With AirbnbPaul Iusztin·Follow5 min read·Jun 28, 2022531ListenSharePhoto by Roman Kraft on UnsplashIntroductionIn the last period, I was considering moving to The Netherlands. I always heard that the countries in the North of Europe are the happiest in the world. Also, I read about their great culture, people, and tech opportunities (yes, I work in tech). In the end, I said to myself that it would be a great experience to try to live in such a country.My first choice was The Netherlands because it is not that far into the North and I already visited Amsterdam, which I liked a lot. I think it had a great vibe. But before taking the big step of moving there, I would like to visit the country for a longer period to see how I would fit into their culture.Now which is the easiest way to travel around these days? You guessed it, with Airbnb or other similar services like Booking.Therefore, I used the data provided by Airbnb to see what would be the best places to rent. The data can be accessed here. It contains a lot of interesting features. Starting from the price & reviews until its availability, on multiple time ranges, of a listing.Airbnb logo. Source.They provide quarterly data for the last 12 months. At the time I wrote this article their last update was on the 5th of June 2022. Therefore the data spans from 05.06.2021 until 05.06.2022.The analysis will contain the biggest cities in The Netherlands: Amsterdam, Rotterdam, and The Hague.Content1️⃣ Which city has the highest price tag? What about their neighborhoods?As we can see in the figure below the most expensive city is Amsterdam. Rotterdam and The Hague are in the same price range.Fig 1: Mean prices per night for the cities.The interesting part comes when we drill down the prices/night in different neighborhoods. In the figure below we can see the cheapest and most expensive neighborhoods. We can see that the prices in Amsterdam don’t vary so much, while in The Hague there are some extravagant neighborhoods you can stay in. Also, if you want to spend as less as possible probably The Hague or Rotterdam is the way to go.Fig 2: Mean prices per night for the neighborhoods.2️⃣ What city and neighborhoods are in most demand?Fig 3: Demand for the cities.In the figure below we can see that people that are going to Amsterdam tend to stick to the mean price which is ~$160. In Rotterdam and The Hague people either choose more expensive properties, around $160 as in Amsterdam, or cheaper ones under $50.Also, the luxurious properties cost more than $500 per night. As you can see that kind of neighborhood are not in the least in-demand group, suggesting that people are willing to pay that kind of money for a luxurious holiday. The neighborhoods that are least in demand are actually having prices close to the mean price of the particular city.Fig 4: Demand for the neighborhoods relative to their price range. The bars are ordered from the ones with the least to the ones with the highest demand.3️⃣ Are reviews for more expensive houses better?Well, the answer is yes and no. We can see that the price ranges between $1000 — $1500 are having the best overall score rating. For this range is a yes. But the really expensive properties, with a range of $1500-$1750, are having the worst performance. Probably people that are booking those kinds of properties are having high expectations or are harder to please.What is good to see is that the lower price ranges of $0–$500 are still having good reviews. Therefore, it is safe to look into that range.Fig 5: USD price range/night relative to their mean review score rating.4️⃣ What are the factors that affect a property’s price?We can see some obvious factors like the number of accommodates, bedrooms and property type. Also, the neighborhood/location has a clear impact on the price.What is more interesting is that the demand for property dictates its price. This is reflected in the availability of 30, 60, 90, and 365 factors (those reflect the number of days a property was free in a specific period).Also, we can see that the number of reviews and when the last one was written have a high impact. One last, interesting observation would be that the period since the host is on Airbnb influence the price. Probably, because he has more experience.Fig 6: Most important factors that influence the price of a property.ConclusionIn this article, we looked at how to book your favorite Airbnb property in The Netherlands by using their public dataset.We looked at the mean price in the biggest cities. I think this is the easiest way, conceptually, to serve a model, but it comes with some downsides. Where the application runs, you need to have the necessary hardware for your model, which sometimes is not possible. In this way, the client can treat the model as a black box. It only has to know the model's inputs and outputs. We usually just buy some specific assets periodically. Often though we get to buy assets when they are at the top of the cycle because we just want to do our monthly finances and don’t want to waste time with any technical analysis. This is fine, but we usually lose some % every month, which over long periods would compound nicely increasing our overall returns.This is where Yacht kicks in. Yacht is a Python package specialized in Order Execution. It is not a trading bot. It is built for the buy and hold investors with the thought to boost their performance. Let’s give an example of how Yacht will be used. We want to invest 1000$ monthly into the SPY ETF. Yacht will listen to the trends of the market in that specific month and tell us when is the best moment to buy. It will also tell us what amount would be best to buy within a specific day. So it will sell nothing, it will just buy a given asset over a month with the idea to buy it below the mean price within that specific month. Long story short, the goal of Yacht is to give you a discount on your favorite assets.Note: The amount of money and the period of one month are just examples. Those can be adjusted to your own needs.This will be a tutorial on how to begin using Yacht. You can see the code on GitHub.Short IntroductionYacht is a Python package. It is a Deep Reinforcement Learning framework for the Financial Market. It is modular and flexible so it is easily adjustable to our own needs. It has environments for Trading and Order Execution. It supports data downloading, processing & caching. Also, it has cool features like Wandb integration and renderers to see how your agent is performing. It supports lots of metrics. An app layer can easily be added to build your ideas on top of it. But it is only in the early stages of its development. Now we are left with 80% which we have to split into train and validation. The easiest way to go would be just to take another 20% into the validation split and train with 60% of the data. There are two reasons why this would not work:We have too little dataWe could overfit the hyper-parameters on the validation split.Cross-validation is trying to solve those problems. The basic approach is called k-fold CV. The algorithm consists in partitioning the train-validation split into k groups. Afterward, take the first group as the validation split and the rest of k-1 as the training split. We repeat this process until every group has been used as a validation split. For our final metrics, take all the k results and average them together. This method is more computationally intensive, but it helps the algorithm to generalize well even with small amounts of data. In the figure below we can see the visual representation of a 5-Fold CV :5-Fold Cross-Validation Example; sourceNote: In some cases, we only have two splits: train and validation , but the same principles apply.Why does K-Fold Cross-Validation Fail in Finance?The k-fold method usually works with the standard data, but in price time series the main issue is that the observations are not independent and identically distributed ( IID). Fractionally Differentiated Features to Preserve Memory in Stationary Time Series | by Paul Iusztin | MLearning.ai | MediumOpen in appSign upSign inWriteSign upSign inMastodonTop highlightMember-only storyFractionally Differentiated Features to Preserve Memory in Stationary Time SeriesHow to Properly Preprocess Data for Machine Learning Trading BotsPaul Iusztin·FollowPublished inMLearning.ai·9 min read·Jan 20, 20221401ListenSharePhoto by Dan-Cristian Pădureț on UnsplashThe method is described from Advances in Financial Machine Learning by Marcos López de Prado.MotivationThe problem of stationarity is often found in time-series data. In this article, I want to give you an intuition on the problem and how to solve it properly without losing you in too many details. If you are interested to dive deep into the topic, I suggest you read: Advances in Financial Machine Learning by Marcos López de Prado. It is really a great book if you are interested in applying Machine Learning in Finance.A Machine Learning algorithm needs the data to be stationary so it can work properly. Before throwing the definition of stationarity I want to give you an intuition about it. Let’s say that we have the price of an asset over a period of time. The training data has prices that vary within the interval [90$; 100$]. The algorithm will learn that everything that is around 90$ is cheap and everything that is around 100$ is expensive. Because the price of an asset moves its mean price over time, the test split will have the price within [100$; 110$]. Now the algorithm will think that the asset is always expensive, even though that is not true because now 100$ is the lowest point. This will mess with the algorithm and it will probably make very strange predictions.Now let's see the definition of stationarity: A time series has stationarity if a shift in time doesn’t cause a change in the shape of the distribution. Basic properties of the distribution like the mean , variance and covariance are constant over time.As an example, we can see in the figure below the prices of Apple from 2021 to 2022.
